required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Comparison of Two Instruments for Stabilization of the Cervix During Office Procedures
clinical_study.official_title: A Comparison of Two Instruments for Stabilization of the Cervix During Office Procedures

brief_summary.textblock:
An Allis clamp causes less pain and bleeding than a single tooth tenaculum when used for mobilization of the cervix during common gynecologic office procedures.
The primary object is to determine the presence of a difference in pain perception between the two instruments.
The secondary objective is to evaluate the differences in the frequency of bleeding, that requires treatment, after removal of the instrument and the need to use an alternative instruments.

primary_outcome.measure: A comparison of two instruments for stabilization of the cervix during office procedures
primary_outcome.description: Primary - to determine the presence of a difference in pain perception between the two instruments.

secondary_outcome.measure: A comparison of two instruments for stabilization of the cervix during office procedures
secondary_outcome.description: Secondary - To evaluate the differences in the frequency of bleeding, that required treatment, after removal of the instruct and the need to use an alternative instrument.

clinical_study.condition: Comparing Two Clamps for Mobilization of the Cervix During Common Gynecologic Office Procedures

study_pop.textblock: Females between the ages of 18 and 89 years undergoing an IUD placement

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female
- Between 18 and 89 years of age
- Undergoing an IUD placement
Exclusion Criteria:
- IUD placement within the last 6 months
- Active cervical or pelvic infection
- pregnant
- Patient taking coagulation medications
